snippet: Computer programs offer a backup for doctors facing tricky symptoms, but are still far from replacing a skilled diagnostician.
abstract: Computers are a valuable tool for doctors attempting to identify diseases in patients, but they may never replace expert diagnosticians like Dr Gurpreet Dhaliwal of San Francisco, considered one of the most skillful clinical diagnosticians in practice today; he exemplifies doctors who can combine logic and knowledge with pattern-matching instincts while overcoming hindrances, like incomplete or imprecise information, that could cause a computer system to makes serious diagnostic errors.
lead_paragraph: Computer programs offer a backup for doctors facing tricky symptoms, but are still far from replacing a skilled diagnostician.

headline.seo: Software Programs Help Doctors Diagnose, but Can’t Replace Them
headline.main: For Second Opinion, Consult a Computer?
headline.print_headline: Could a Computer Outthink This Doctor?
